articles.headline: Instant Love, Followed by Letdown
articles.snippet: Your heart will beat faster, at least for a time, when you handle the new Olympus EP-1, which combines the size of a pocket camera with S.L.R. quality.
articles.abstract: Your heart will beat faster, at least for a time, when you handle the new Olympus EP-1, which combines the size of a pocket camera with S.L.R. quality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Technology is like romance. When everything clicks, you’re on top of the world  but every now and then, your heart gets broken.

articles.headline: Trustee Sues Ruth Madoff for Nearly $45 Million
articles.snippet: The trustee, Irving H. Picard, claimed Mrs. Madoff received tens of millions of dollars from her husband’s investment firm, enabling her to live a “life of splendor.”
articles.abstract: The trustee, Irving H. Picard, claimed Mrs. Madoff received tens of millions of dollars from her husband’s investment firm, enabling her to live a “life of splendor.”
articles.lead_paragraph: She lost the penthouse on New York’s Upper East Side, the compound in Palm Beach, Fla., the home in Montauk on Long Island and the house in the south of France. The yacht, the Mercedes, the Russian sable coat, the Steinway piano  all gone.

articles.headline: New Poll Finds Growing Unease on Health Plan
articles.snippet: President Obama’s ability to shape the debate on health care appears to be waning as opponents portray the effort as a government takeover, according to a Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s ability to shape the debate on health care appears to be waning as opponents portray the effort as a government takeover, according to a Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s ability to shape the debate on health care appears to be eroding as opponents aggressively portray his overhaul plan as a government takeover that could limit Americans’ ability to choose their doctors and course of treatment, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Chinese Workers Say Illness Is Real, Not Hysteria
articles.snippet: Officials said breathing difficulty and paralysis that affected more than 1,000 were mass hysteria.
articles.abstract: Officials said breathing difficulty and paralysis that affected more than 1,000 were mass hysteria.
articles.lead_paragraph: JILIN CITY, China  Tian Lihua was just beginning her morning shift when she felt a wave of nausea, then numbness in her limbs and finally dizziness that gave way to unconsciousness. In the days that followed, more than 1,200 fellow employees at the textile mill where Ms. Tian works would be felled by these and other symptoms, including convulsions, breathing difficulties, vomiting and temporary paralysis.

articles.headline: Increasing Postal Deficits Intensify Talks on Solution
articles.snippet: The postmaster general expects a $7 billion deficit this year, up from a projection of $6 billion just months ago.
articles.abstract: The postmaster general expects a $7 billion deficit this year, up from a projection of $6 billion just months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The debate over how Congress can best ease the financial woes of the United States Postal Service is likely to intensify in coming months as the Postal Service’s record-breaking losses continue to escalate.

articles.headline: Once-Mothballed Taurus Is Back on Stage at Ford
articles.snippet: Ford’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, figured the Taurus name still had value, even though it had become a staple of rental car fleets.
articles.abstract: Ford’s chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, figured the Taurus name still had value, even though it had become a staple of rental car fleets.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.  After a 20-year run, the Ford Taurus was headed for the scrap heap in 2007. The automaker planned to retire the name, and call its new sedan the Ford Five Hundred instead.

articles.headline: Lucrative Fees May Deter Efforts to Alter Loans
articles.snippet: Many mortgage companies that make big profits on late fees are reluctant to give strapped homeowners a break.
articles.abstract: Many mortgage companies that make big profits on late fees are reluctant to give strapped homeowners a break.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the Obama administration summoned mortgage company executives to Washington to demand they move faster to lower payments for homeowners sliding toward foreclosure. Treasury officials called on the companies to hire and train more people quickly to field applications for relief.

articles.headline: Texas Hospital Flexing Muscle in Health Fight
articles.snippet: A major source of campaign contributions for Senate Democrats is a physician-owned hospital that is trying to soften health care legislation.
articles.abstract: A major source of campaign contributions for Senate Democrats is a physician-owned hospital that is trying to soften health care legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex.  One of the largest sources of campaign contributions to Senate Democrats during this year’s health care debate is a physician-owned hospital in one of the country’s poorest regions that has sought to soften measures that could choke its rapid growth.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Profit Dropped 66% at Exxon Mobil
articles.snippet: Exxon’s report caps a week of lower earnings in the energy industry after the tumble of oil prices since last year.
articles.abstract: Exxon’s report caps a week of lower earnings in the energy industry after the tumble of oil prices since last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil’s stellar earnings growth in recent years had hardly disappointed its investors. But now, the company whose profit for last year was the largest in corporate history is slipping in its performance.

articles.headline: U.S. Adviser’s Blunt Memo on Iraq: Time ‘to Go Home’
articles.snippet: A senior American military adviser says that the Iraqi forces suffer from deeply entrenched deficiencies, but that extending the stay of U.S. forces won’t help.
articles.abstract: A senior American military adviser says that the Iraqi forces suffer from deeply entrenched deficiencies, but that extending the stay of U.S. forces won’t help.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A senior American military adviser in Baghdad has concluded in an unusually blunt memo that Iraqi forces suffer from entrenched deficiencies but are now able to protect the Iraqi government, and that it is time “for the U.S. to declare victory and go home.”
